item.description:
We are pleased to announce John Pawelek, PhD, will join us with a fascinating talk on the mechanisms by which we make melanin in our skins and the health and social issues surrounding skin pigmentation.

A long-time cancer researcher at the Yale School of Medicine, Department of Dermatology and the Yale Cancer Center, Dr. Pawelek is a world-renowned expert on both normal and abnormal conditions related to cells that produce melanins. He has published over 200 peer-reviewed articles and has won numerous awards for his work.

Melanins are pigments in the skin that play many roles in biology including camouflage, species and gender recognition, heat exchange, and protection from ultraviolet light. The more melanin you have in your skin, the less sun damage. While there are many beneficial roles for melanin, unfortunately the amount and distribution of skin melanin can cause some people to be perceived as “different” from the rest of society, evoking negative discrimination against them.

We'll start with a half hour of coffee and conversation at 7:30 p.m. and the main talk will follow brief announcements at 8:00 PM.

For more information about this event and others, please read the write-up on our home page.
